title: Meaning of Slope in Speed and Mileage Relationship
question_text:
The speed (in kilometers per hour) and mileage (in kilometers per liter) of $13\text{ cars}$ was measured. The regression equation is as follows:
$$\text{Mileage (km per liter)}= -1.8 + 0.536 \times \text{Speed (km per hour)}$$
According to this model, an increase in speed of $10$ kilometers per hour would change the fuel economy by
According to this model, an increase in speed of $10$ kilometers per hour would change the fuel economy by
tables:

Constant-1.88.357-0.220.8333

choices.text: An increase of $5.36\text{ kilometers per liter}$.
A decrease of $5.36\text{ kilometers per liter}$.
A decrease of $1.8\text{ kilometers per liter}$.
An increase of $0.536\text{ kilometers per liter}$.
An increase in 8.357 kilometers per liter.

solution:
We are asked about how an increase in speed would change the fuel economy. In other words, speed is like the independent variable, x
, and fuel economy is like the dependent variable, y
. To find how y
changes with respect to x
, we need the slope. By definition, the slope is the change in y
divided by the change in x
. We need to look at our given equation to understand what these numbers are.

Looking at the equation, if we increase speed by 1
, mileage increases by 0.536
. So if speed changes by 10
, fuel economy changes by 5.36
.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'A'.

Common Error

A common error is to calculate the mileage at 10 km per hour
:

Mileage (km per liter)=−1.8+0.536×Speed (km per hour)

Mileage (km per liter)=−1.8+0.536×10

Mileage (km per liter)=−1.8+5.36

Mileage (km per liter)=3.56

This is the mileage at 10 km per hour
, but it does not represent the change in fuel economy. That is only the term 0.536×Speed (km per hour)
.
